name: Appeal to Probability
description: Taking something for granted because it would probably be the case (or might possibly be the case).

name: Argument from Fallacy
description: The assumption that, if a particular argument for a conclusion is fallacious, then the conclusion by itself is false.

name: Base Rate Fallacy
description: Making a probability judgment based on conditional probabilities, without taking into account the effect of prior probabilities.

name: Conjunction Fallacy
description: The assumption that an outcome simultaneously satisfying multiple conditions is more probable than an outcome satisfying a single one of them.

name: Non Sequitur Fallacy
description: Where the conclusion does not logically follow the premise.

name: Masked-Man Fallacy
description: The substitution of identical designators in a true statement can lead to a false one.

name: Affirming a Disjunct
description: Concluding that one disjunct of a logical disjunction must be false because the other disjunct is true; A or B; A, therefore not B.

name: Affirming the Consequent
description: The antecedent in an indicative conditional is claimed to be true because the consequent is true; if A, then B; B, therefore A.

name: Denying the Antecedent
description: The consequent in an indicative conditional is claimed to be false because the antecedent is false; if A, then B; not A, therefore not B.

name: Existential Fallacy
description: An argument that has a universal premise and a particular conclusion.

name: Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise
description: A categorical syllogism has a positive conclusion, but at least one negative premise.

name: Fallacy of Exclusive Premises
description: A categorical syllogism that is invalid because both of its premises are negative.

name: Fallacy of Four Terms
description: A categorical syllogism that has four terms.

name: Illicit Major
description: A categorical syllogism that is invalid because its major term is not distributed in the major premise but distributed in the conclusion.

name: Illicit Minor
description: A categorical syllogism that is invalid because its minor term is not distributed in the minor premise but distributed in the conclusion.

name: Negative Conclusion from Affirmative Premises
description: A categorical syllogism has a negative conclusion but affirmative premises.

name: Fallacy of the Undistributed Middle
description: The middle term in a categorical syllogism is not distributed.

name: Modal Fallacy
description: Confusing necessity with sufficiency.

name: Modal Scope Fallacy
description: A degree of unwarranted necessity is placed in the conclusion.

name: Argument from Incredulity
description: When someone can't imagine something to be true, and therefore deems it false, or conversely, holds that it must be true because they can't see how it could be false.

name: Argument to Moderation
description: Assuming that a compromise between two positions is always correct.
also_known_as: False compromise, Middle ground, Fallacy of the mean, Argumentum ad temperantiam

name: Continuum Fallacy
description: Improperly rejecting a claim for being imprecise.
also_known_as: Fallacy of the beard, Line-drawing fallacy, Sorites fallacy, Fallacy of the heap, Bald man fallacy, Decision-point fallacy

name: Suppressed Correlative
description: A correlative is redefined so that one alternative is made impossible (e.g., "I'm not fat because I'm thinner than John.").

name: Definist Fallacy
description: Defining a term used in an argument in a biased manner (e.g., using 'loaded terms'). The person making the argument expects that the listener will accept the provided definition, making the argument difficult to refute.

name: Divine Fallacy
description: Arguing that, because something is so phenomenal or amazing, it must be the result of superior, divine, alien, or paranormal agency.

name: Double Counting
description: Counting events or occurrences more than once in probabilistic reasoning, which leads to the sum of the probabilities of all cases exceeding unity.

name: Equivocation
description: Using a term with more than one meaning in a statement without specifying which meaning is intended.

name: Ambiguous Middle Term
description: Using a middle term with multiple meanings.

name: Definitional Retreat
description: Changing the meaning of a word when an objection is raised. Often paired with moving the goalposts, as when an argument is challenged using a common definition of a term in the argument, and the arguer presents a different definition of the term and thereby demands different evidence to debunk the argument.

name: Motte-and-Bailey Fallacy
description: Conflating two positions with similar properties, one modest and easy to defend (the 'motte') and one more controversial (the 'bailey'). The arguer first states the controversial position, but when challenged, states that they are advancing the modest position.

name: Fallacy of Accent
description: Changing the meaning of a statement by not specifying on which word emphasis falls.

name: Persuasive Definition
description: Purporting to use the 'true' or 'commonly accepted' meaning of a term while, in reality, using an uncommon or altered definition.

name: If-by-Whiskey
description: An argument that supports both sides of an issue by using terms that are emotionally sensitive and ambiguous.

name: Ecological Fallacy
description: Inferring about the nature of an entity based solely upon aggregate statistics collected for the group to which that entity belongs.

name: Etymological Fallacy
description: Assuming that the original or historical meaning of a word or phrase is necessarily similar to its actual present-day usage.

name: Fallacy of Composition
description: Assuming that something true of part of a whole must also be true of the whole.

name: Fallacy of Division
description: Assuming that something true of a composite thing must also be true of all or some of its parts.

name: False Attribution
description: Appealing to an irrelevant, unqualified, unidentified, biased or fabricated source in support of an argument.

name: Fallacy of Quoting Out of Context
description: Selective excerpting of words from their original context to distort the intended meaning.

name: False Authority
description: Using an expert of dubious credentials or using only one opinion to promote a product or idea. Related to the appeal to authority fallacy.

name: False Dilemma
description: Two alternative statements are given as the only possible options when, in reality, there are more.
also_known_as: False Dichotomy, Fallacy of Bifurcation, Black-or-White Fallacy

name: False Equivalence
description: Describing two or more statements as virtually equal when they are not.

name: Feedback Fallacy
description: Believing in the objectivity of an evaluation to be used as the basis for improvement without verifying that the source of the evaluation is a disinterested party.

name: Historian's Fallacy
description: Assuming that decision-makers of the past had identical information as those subsequently analyzing the decision. This is not to be confused with presentism, in which present-day ideas and perspectives are anachronistically projected into the past.

name: Historical Fallacy
description: Believing that certain results occurred only because a specific process was performed, though said process may actually be unrelated to the results.

name: Baconian Fallacy
description: Supposing that historians can obtain the 'whole truth' via induction from individual pieces of historical evidence. The 'whole truth' is defined as learning 'something about everything', 'everything about something', or 'everything about everything'. In reality, a historian 'can only hope to know something about something'.

name: Homunculus Fallacy
description: Using a 'middle-man' for explanation; this sometimes leads to regressive middle-men. It explains a concept in terms of the concept itself without explaining its real nature (e.g.: explaining thought as something produced by a little thinker – a homunculus – inside the head simply identifies an intermediary actor and does not explain the product or process of thinking).

name: Inflation of Conflict
description: Arguing that, if experts in a field of knowledge disagree on a certain point within that field, no conclusion can be reached or that the legitimacy of that field of knowledge is questionable.

name: Incomplete Comparison
description: Insufficient information is provided to make a complete comparison.

name: Intentionality Fallacy
description: The insistence that the ultimate meaning of an expression must be consistent with the intention of the person from whom the communication originated.

name: Kettle Logic
description: Using multiple, jointly inconsistent arguments to defend a position.

name: Ludic Fallacy
description: Failing to take into account that non-regulated random occurrences (unknown unknowns) can affect the probability of an event taking place.

name: Lump of Labour Fallacy
description: The misconception that there is a fixed amount of work to be done within an economy, which can be distributed to create more or fewer jobs.

name: McNamara fallacy
description: Making an argument using only quantitative observations (measurements, statistical or numerical values) and discounting subjective information that focuses on quality (traits, features, or relationships).

name: Mind projection fallacy
description: Assuming that a statement about an object describes an inherent property of the object, rather than a personal perception.

name: Moralistic fallacy
description: Inferring factual conclusions from evaluative premises in violation of fact–value distinction (e.g.: inferring is from ought).

name: Moving the goalposts
description: Argument in which evidence presented in response to a specific claim is dismissed and some other (often greater) evidence is demanded.

name: Nirvana fallacy
description: Solutions to problems are rejected because they are not perfect.

name: Package deal
description: Treating essentially dissimilar concepts as though they were essentially similar.

name: Proof by assertion
description: A proposition is repeatedly restated regardless of contradiction.
also_known_as: argumentum ad infinitum, argumentum ad nauseam

name: Prosecutor's fallacy
description: A low probability of false matches does not mean a low probability of some false match being found.

name: Proving too much
description: An argument that results in an overly generalized conclusion (e.g.: arguing that drinking alcohol is bad because in some instances it has led to spousal or child abuse).

name: Psychologist's fallacy
description: An observer presupposes the objectivity of their own perspective when analyzing a behavioral event.

name: Referential fallacy
description: Assuming that all words refer to existing things and that the meaning of words reside within the things they refer to, as opposed to words possibly referring to no real object or that the meaning comes from how they are used.

name: Reification
description: Treating an abstract belief or hypothetical construct as if it were a concrete, real event or physical entity.
also_known_as: concretism, hypostatization, fallacy of misplaced concreteness

name: Retrospective determinism
description: Believing that, because an event has occurred under some circumstance, the circumstance must have made the event inevitable.

name: Slippery slope
description: Asserting that a proposed, relatively small, first action will inevitably lead to a chain of related events resulting in a significant and negative event and, therefore, should not be permitted.
also_known_as: thin edge of the wedge, camel's nose

name: Special pleading
description: The arguer attempts to cite something as an exemption to a generally accepted rule or principle without justifying the exemption.

name: Accident
description: An exception to a generalization is ignored.

name: No true Scotsman
description: Makes a generalization true by changing the generalization to exclude a counterexample.

name: Cherry picking
description: Using individual cases or data that confirm a particular position, while ignoring related cases or data that may contradict that position.
also_known_as: suppressed evidence, incomplete evidence, argument by half-truth, fallacy of exclusion, card stacking, slanting

name: Nut-picking
description: Using individual cases or data that falsify a particular position, while ignoring related cases or data that may support that position.

name: Survivorship bias
description: A small number of successes of a given process are actively promoted while completely ignoring a large number of failures.

name: False analogy
description: An argument by analogy in which the analogy is poorly suited.

name: Hasty generalization
description: Basing a broad conclusion on a small or unrepresentative sample.
also_known_as: fallacy of insufficient statistics, fallacy of insufficient sample, fallacy of the lonely fact, hasty induction, secundum quid, converse accident, jumping to conclusions

name: Argument from anecdote
description: A fallacy where anecdotal evidence is presented as an argument; without any other contributory evidence or reasoning.

name: Inductive fallacy
description: A fallacy of induction happens when a conclusion is drawn from premises that only lightly support it.

name: Misleading vividness
description: Involves describing an occurrence in vivid detail, even if it is an exceptional occurrence, to convince someone that it is more important.

name: Overwhelming exception
description: An accurate generalization that comes with qualifications that eliminate so many cases that what remains is much less impressive than the initial statement might have led one to assume.

name: Thought-terminating cliché
description: A commonly used phrase, sometimes passing as folk wisdom, used to quell cognitive dissonance, conceal lack of forethought, move on to other topics, etc. – but in any case, to end the debate with a cliché rather than a point.

name: Cum hoc ergo propter hoc
description: A faulty assumption that, because there is a correlation between two variables, one caused the other.
also_known_as: correlation implies causation, faulty cause/effect, coincidental correlation, correlation without causation

name: Post hoc ergo propter hoc
description: X happened, then Y happened; therefore X caused Y.

name: Wrong direction
description: Cause and effect are reversed. The cause is said to be the effect and vice versa. The consequence of the phenomenon is claimed to be its root cause.

name: Ignoring a common cause
description: The third-cause fallacy is a logical fallacy in which a spurious relationship is confused for causation. It asserts that X causes Y when in reality, both X and Y are caused by Z. It is a variation on the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy and a member of the questionable cause group of fallacies.
examples: Sleeping with one's shoes on is strongly correlated with waking up with a headache. Therefore, sleeping with one's shoes on causes headache.
Young children who sleep with the light on are much more likely to develop myopia in later life. Therefore, sleeping with the light on causes myopia.
As ice cream sales increase, the rate of drowning deaths increases sharply. Therefore, ice cream consumption causes drowning.

name: Fallacy of the single cause
description: It is assumed that there is one, simple cause of an outcome when in reality it may have been caused by a number of only jointly sufficient causes.

name: Furtive fallacy
description: Outcomes are asserted to have been caused by the malfeasance of decision makers.

name: Magical thinking
description: Fallacious attribution of causal relationships between actions and events. In anthropology, it refers primarily to cultural beliefs that ritual, prayer, sacrifice, and taboos will produce specific supernatural consequences. In psychology, it refers to an irrational belief that thoughts by themselves can affect the world or that thinking something corresponds with doing it.

name: Observational interpretation fallacy
description: Occurs when associations identified in observational studies are misinterpreted as causal relationships.

name: Regression fallacy
description: Ascribes cause where none exists. The flaw is failing to account for natural fluctuations. It is frequently a special kind of post hoc fallacy.

name: Gambler's fallacy
description: The incorrect belief that separate, independent events can affect the likelihood of another random event. If a fair coin lands on heads 10 times in a row, the belief that it is "due to the number of times it had previously landed on tails" is incorrect.

name: Inverse gambler's fallacy
description: The inverse of the gambler's fallacy. It is the incorrect belief that on the basis of an unlikely outcome, the process must have happened many times before.

name: p-hacking
description: Belief in the significance of a result, not realizing that multiple comparisons or experiments have been run and only the most significant were published.

name: Garden of forking paths fallacy
description: Incorrect belief that a single experiment can not be subject to the multiple comparisons effect.

name: Sunk costs fallacy
description: Refusal to leave a situation because you have already put large amounts of time or effort into it- for example trying to jump over a wall you physically cannot jump over because you have already spent an hour trying to jump.

name: Red herring
description: Introducing a second argument in response to the first argument that is irrelevant and draws attention away from the original topic (e.g.: saying "If you want to complain about the dishes I leave in the sink, what about the dirty clothes you leave in the bathroom?").

name: Ad hominem
description: Attacking the arguer instead of the argument. (Note that "ad hominem" can also refer to the dialectical strategy of arguing on the basis of the opponent's own commitments. This type of ad hominem is not a fallacy.)

name: Circumstantial ad hominem
description: Stating that the arguer's personal situation or perceived benefit from advancing a conclusion means that their conclusion is wrong.

name: Poisoning the well
description: A subtype of ad hominem presenting adverse information about a target person with the intention of discrediting everything that the target person says.

name: Appeal to motive
description: Dismissing an idea by questioning the motives of its proposer.

name: Tone policing
description: Focusing on emotion behind (or resulting from) a message rather than the message itself as a discrediting tactic.

name: Traitorous critic fallacy
description: A critic's perceived affiliation is portrayed as the underlying reason for the criticism and the critic is asked to stay away from the issue altogether.

name: Bulverism
description: Inferring why an argument is being used, associating it to some psychological reason, then assuming it is invalid as a result. The assumption that if the origin of an idea comes from a biased mind, then the idea itself must also be a falsehood.

name: Appeal to authority
description: An assertion is deemed true because of the position or authority of the person asserting it.
also_known_as: argument from authority, argumentum ad verecundiam

name: Appeal to accomplishment
description: An assertion is deemed true or false based on the accomplishments of the proposer.

name: Courtier's reply
description: A criticism is dismissed by claiming that the critic lacks sufficient knowledge, credentials, or training to credibly comment on the subject matter.

name: Appeal to emotion
description: Manipulating the emotions of the listener rather than using valid reasoning to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to fear
description: Generating distress, anxiety, cynicism, or prejudice towards the opponent in an argument.

name: Appeal to flattery
description: Using excessive or insincere praise to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to pity
description: Generating feelings of sympathy or mercy in the listener to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to ridicule
description: Mocking or stating that the opponent's position is laughable to deflect from the merits of the opponent's argument.

name: Appeal to spite
description: Generating bitterness or hostility in the listener toward an opponent in an argument.

name: Judgmental language
description: Using insulting or pejorative language in an argument.

name: Pooh-pooh
description: Stating that an opponent's argument is unworthy of consideration.

name: Style over substance
description: Embellishing an argument with compelling language, exploiting a bias towards the esthetic qualities of an argument, e.g. the rhyme-as-reason effect

name: Wishful thinking
description: Arguing for a course of action by the listener according to what might be pleasing to imagine rather than according to evidence or reason.

name: Appeal to nature
description: Judgment is based solely on whether the subject of judgment is 'natural' or 'unnatural'.
also_known_as: naturalistic fallacy (not to be confused with other fallacies by that name)

name: Appeal to novelty
description: A proposal is claimed to be superior or better solely because it is new or modern.

name: Appeal to poverty
description: Supporting a conclusion because the arguer is poor (or refuting because the arguer is wealthy).

name: Appeal to tradition
description: A conclusion supported solely because it has long been held to be true.

name: Appeal to wealth
description: Supporting a conclusion because the arguer is wealthy (or refuting because the arguer is poor).

name: Argumentum ad baculum
description: An argument made through coercion or threats of force to support position.
also_known_as: appeal to the stick, appeal to force, appeal to threat

name: Argumentum ad populum
description: A proposition is claimed to be true or good solely because a majority or many people believe it to be so.
also_known_as: appeal to widespread belief, bandwagon argument, appeal to the majority, appeal to the people

name: Association fallacy
description: Arguing that because two things share (or are implied to share) some property, they are the same.
also_known_as: guilt by association and honor by association

name: Logic chopping fallacy
description: Focusing on trivial details of an argument, rather than the main point of the argumentation.

name: Ipse dixit
description: A claim that is presented as true without support, as self-evidently true, or as dogmatically true. This fallacy relies on the implied expertise of the speaker or on an unstated truism.

name: Chronological snobbery
description: A thesis is deemed incorrect because it was commonly held when something else, known to be false, was also commonly held.

name: Fallacy of relative privation
description: Dismissing an argument or complaint due to what are perceived to be more important problems. First World problems are a subset of this fallacy.
also_known_as: appeal to worse problems, not as bad as

name: Genetic fallacy
description: A conclusion is suggested based solely on something or someone's origin rather than its current meaning or context.

name: I'm entitled to my opinion
description: A person discredits any opposition by claiming that they are entitled to their opinion.

name: Moralistic fallacy
description: Inferring factual conclusions from evaluative premises, in violation of fact–value distinction; e.g. making statements about what is, on the basis of claims about what ought to be.

name: Straw man
description: Refuting an argument different from the one actually under discussion, while not recognizing or acknowledging the distinction.

name: Texas sharpshooter fallacy
description: Improperly asserting a cause to explain a cluster of data.

name: Tu quoque
description: Stating that a position is false, wrong, or should be disregarded because its proponent fails to act consistently in accordance with it.
also_known_as: you too, appeal to hypocrisy, whataboutism

name: Two wrongs make a right
description: Assuming that, if one wrong is committed, another wrong will rectify it.

name: Vacuous truth
description: A claim that is technically true but meaningless, in the form no A in B has C, when there is no A in B. For example, claiming that no mobile phones in the room are on when there are no mobile phones in the room.
